sec.title: Website of the month
sec.p: In 2010, about 22 000 people in the UK were living with undiagnosed human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). Halve It is ‘a coalition of national experts determined to tackle the continued public health challenges posed by HIV’. The campaign, launched in 2010, aims by 2015 to halve the proportion of people diagnosed late with HIV and those living with undiagnosed HIV. By encouraging early diagnosis, the aims are to achieve better individual health and reduce new infection rates. The website offers a plethora of information relevant to general practice.
Health Protection Agency (2011). HIV in the United Kingdom: 2011 Report. Retrieved from www.hpa.org.uk/webc/HPAwebFile/HPAweb_C/1317131685847

sec.title: Supporting carers in general practice
sec.p: A total of 12% of patients who visit their GPs are carers. A training resource for GPs has been developed to improve the quality of care for these carers, because being a carer comes at a cost. Up to 40% experience psychological distress or depression, one in five gives up work to care and more than half fall into debt as a result of caring.

As part of this programme, an in-house training DVD has been designed for GPs and practice staff, which counts towards continuing professional development. These can be obtained by emailing supportingcarers@rcgp.org.uk. Further information is available on the RCGP dedicated page, including a link to ‘Supporting carers: an action guide for general practitioners’ and an online e-learning programme.
There are likely to be performance-related pay incentives for improved identification of and assessment of carers within primary care.
RCGP. Supporting carers in general practice. Retrieved from www.rcgp.org.uk/revalidation-and-cpd/substance-misuse-and-associated-health/supporting-carers-in-general-practice.aspx

sec.title: GP Workload Survey 2013
sec.p: The Southwest United Kingdom Local Medical Committees released an interesting survey on workload. Over 2700 GPs out of about 6000 responded to the survey. The findings highlight a major concern regarding the viability and safety of working in the face of longer hours and heavier, more complex workloads, coupled with underfunding.
Wessex Local Medical Committees (2013). Press Release: GP Workload Survey January 2013. Retrieved from www.wessexlmcs.com/Press_Release_GP_Workload_Survey

sec.title: Critical reading for primary care
sec.p: The British Journal of General Practice has created a free on-line resource on reading and appraising the quality of research articles. The resource is divided into seven main chapters looking at different research methods as exemplified by a set of articles published in the BJGP over 2011.

sec.title: PEARLS
sec.p: The British Journal of General Practice is publishing summaries of Cochrane reviews; Practical Evidence About Real Life Situations or PEARLS. This is part of an attempt to make Cochrane more relevant to primary care and the organisation is looking for expressions of interest from anyone involved in primary care.

sec.title: Health care for migrants
sec.p: Reflecting on my patient satisfaction questionnaire responses made me wonder which patient groups do not complete questionnaires. In London we have groups of patients who struggle to access care. One of these groups is asylum-seekers.

In primary care there are NO regulations about charging or eligibility for care. All GPs can choose which patients to accept; but we must not discriminate. We have a professional obligation to refer to secondary care when we deem clinically appropriate. Eligibility for free care varies around the United Kingdom but there are categories of illness, e.g. infectious diseases, and categories of patient, e.g. victims of human trafficking that are exempt from charges.
How does your practice deal with people trying to register? Are they all treated in the same way?
Health Protection Agency (2012). Migrant health guide. Retrieved from www.hpa.org.uk/MigrantHealthGuide/

sec.title: British National Formulary
sec.p: Health professionals have free access to the BNF and can sign up for monthly email updates. January’s update included information about the reorganised palliative care section. I think the tables of opioid dose conversions, including equivalent doses for transdermal delivery are useful. When I did a radiotherapy post I could do the conversions without looking them up, but I now find our Macmillan nurses invaluable as a source of advice for analgesia and symptom control and advice about what can be mixed in a syringe driver.

sec.title: Insomnia and non-benzodiazepine hypnotics
sec.p: A meta-analysis of randomised-controlled trials of the ‘Z' drugs eszopiclone, zaleplon and zolpidem was performed to investigate their effectiveness and placebo effects. Thirteen studies with 4378 participants were analysed. Results showed that Z drugs decreased polysomnographic sleep latency by 22 minutes compared with placebo and by 7 minutes for subjective sleep latency. The authors comment that both results are small, non-clinically significant effects. They conclude the placebo response is the major contributor to the effectiveness of Z drugs, which should be balanced against harms. They suggest that psychological interventions should be given more emphasis in insomnia management.
In January 2013, the RCGP and the Royal College of Psychiatrists released a consensus statement aimed at reducing patient addiction to medicines such as tranquillisers.

Huedo-medina, T., Kirsch, I., Middlemass, J., Klonizakis, M. & Siriwardena, N. (2012). Effectiveness of non-benzodiazepine hypnotics in treatment of adult insomnia: meta-analysis of data submitted to the Food and Drug Administration. British Medical Journal, 345, doi: 10.1136/bmj.e8343
RCGP (2013). Medical bodies unite to combat addiction to medicines. Retrieved from www.rcgp.org.uk/news/2013/january/addiction-to-medicines-consensus-statement.aspx

sec.title: Detecting atrial fibrillation
sec.p: The National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence (NICE) has backed the use of WatchBP Home, a blood pressure machine that can detect atrial fibrillation, for opportunistically detecting asymptomatic atrial fibrillation during the measurement of blood pressure by primary care professionals.
NICE (2013). NICE guidance supports new blood pressure device that can detect atrial fibrillation. Retrieved from www.nice.org.uk/newsroom/pressreleases/NICEGuidanceSupportsNewBloodPressureDevice.jsp

sec.title: Controversy about the Liverpool Care Pathway
sec.p:
I think it is very sad that publicity about poorly handled patient care has frightened patients and their relatives about the Liverpool Care Pathway. The original aim was to provide the best possible care for people in the last few days and hours of life. The Marie Curie Palliative Care Institute has produced 10 key messages to try to dispel some of the myths and restore faith in the process:
The LCP is only as good as the people who are using it.
The LCP should not be used without the support of education and training.
Good communication is pivotal to success.
The LCP neither hastens nor postpones death.
Diagnosis of dying should be made by the multidisciplinary team.
The LCP does not recommend the use of continuous deep sedation.
The LCP does not preclude the use of artificial hydration.
The LCP supports continual reassessment.
Reflect, audit, measure and learn
Stop, think, assess, change.

sec.title: Breast cancer resource packs
sec.p: Breast Cancer Care has just updated its secondary breast cancer resource pack (there are other resource packs including primary breast cancer and ‘worried about breast cancer’). This is a long document with advice about diagnosis, treatment, both conventional and complementary, support and palliative care. The document may be too long for some patients but downloading parts at a time might be helpful. The documents are available free of charge as a downloadable.pdf file or as hard copy.
Breast Cancer Care. Secondary resource pack (BCC173). Retrieved from www2.breastcancercare.org.uk/publications/secondary-breast-cancer/secondary-resource-pack-bcc173

sec.title: Controversy over breast screening
sec.p: There has been another article in the British Medical Journal where Professor Michael Baum queries the value of the NHS breast screening programme.

I wonder if you feel able to have conversations with patients where you discuss the risks and benefits of the various cancer screening programmes. In revising for the Clinical Skills Assessment it might be worth practising how you discuss risks and benefits with patients.
Baum, M. (2013). Harms from breast cancer screening outweigh benefits. British Medical Journal, 346, f385, doi: 10.1136/bmj.f385
